translated: Monks, neither Brahmā, the lord of the assembly, nor Śakra, lord of the gods, nor the four world guardians came to see me.

original: api tu devadattena madvadhāyodyuktena yā gṛddhrakūṭaparvatād yantreṇa śilā kṣiptā sā antarīkṣe eva vajrapāṇinā vajreṇa cūrṇitā /
analyzed: api tu devadattena mad vadhāya udyuktena yā gṛddhrakūṭa parvatāt yantreṇa śilā kṣiptā sā antarīkṣe eva vajrapāṇinā vajreṇa cūrṇitā
translated: Rather, Devadatta, who was intent on killing me, threw a rock from Vulture Peak Mountain with a machine, and it was pulverized by Vajrapāṇi with his thunderbolt right there in the sky.

original: tasyā ardhaṃ mamopari patamānaṃ kumbhīrayakṣeṇa durgṛhītaṃ kṛtaṃ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ ardham mama upari patamānam kumbhīra yakṣeṇa durgṛhītam kṛtam
translated: Half of it, falling on me, was poorly grasped by the yakṣa Kumbhīra.

original: sa tena praghātito mamāntike cittam abhiprasādya kālagataḥ /
analyzed: sa tena praghātitaḥ mama antike cittam abhiprasādya kālagataḥ
translated: He was killed by that, and having conceived faith in me, died.

analyzed: praṇīteṣu deveṣu trayastriṃśeṣu a
translated: He was reborn among the gods of the excellent heaven of the thirty-three.

original: upapannaḥ / sa imāṃ rātriṃ matsakāśam upasaṃkrāntaḥ /
analyzed: upapannaḥ saḥ imām rātrim mad sakāśam upasaṃkrāntaḥ
translated: He came to me in the night.

analyzed: tasya mayā dharmaḥ deśitaḥ
translated: The Dharma was taught to him by me.

analyzed: sa dṛṣṭi satyaḥ sva bhavanam gataḥ
translated: Having seen the truth, he went to his own abode.

original: iti hi bhikṣavaḥ ekāntakṛṣṇānāṃ karmaṇām ekāntakṛṣṇo vipākaḥ /
analyzed: iti hi bhikṣavaḥ ekānta kṛṣṇānām karmaṇām ekānta kṛṣṇaḥ vipākaḥ
translated: Thus, monks, the ripening of actions that are entirely dark is entirely dark.

analyzed: ekānta śuklānām ekānta śuklaḥ
translated: For those of completely white [actions], the result is completely white.

analyzed: vyatimiśrāṇām vyatimiśraḥ
translated: For those of mixed [actions], the result is mixed.

original: tasmāt tarhi bhikṣavaḥ ekāntakṛṣṇāni karmāṇy apāsya vyatimiśrāṇi ca ekāntaśukleṣv eva karmasv ābhogāḥ karaṇīyaḥ ity evaṃ vo bhikṣavaḥ śikṣitavyam
analyzed: tasmāt tarhi bhikṣavaḥ ekānta kṛṣṇāni karmāṇi apāsya vyatimiśrāṇi ca ekānta śukleṣu eva karmasu ābhogāḥ karaṇīyaḥ iti evam vaḥ bhikṣavaḥ śikṣitavyam
translated: Therefore, monks, having abandoned completely black actions and mixed [actions], you should apply yourselves only to completely white actions. Thus, monks, you should train.

original: bhikṣavaḥ saṃśayajātāḥ sarvasaṃśayacchettāraṃ buddhaṃ bhagavantaṃ papracchuḥ /
analyzed: bhikṣavaḥ saṃśaya jātāḥ sarva saṃśaya chettāram buddham bhagavantam papracchuḥ
translated: The monks, being doubtful, asked the Blessed One, who resolves all doubts,

original: paśya bhadanta kumbhīreṇa yakṣeṇa bhagavataḥ arthāya ātmā parityaktaḥ iti /
analyzed: paśya bhadanta kumbhīreṇa yakṣeṇa bhagavataḥ arthāya ātmā parityaktaḥ iti
translated: Venerable sir, see how the yaksha Kumbhira sacrificed himself for the sake of the Blessed One.

analyzed: bhagavān āha
translated: The Blessed One said,

original: na bhikṣava etarhi yathā atīte 'py adhvani anena mamārthāya ātmā parityaktaḥ /
analyzed: na bhikṣavaḥ etarhi yathā atīte pi adhvani anena mama arthāya ātmā parityaktaḥ
translated: Monks, not only now, but also in the past, he sacrificed himself for my sake.

analyzed: tat śrūyatām
translated: Listen to that.

analyzed: the story of a hunter
translated: The story of the hunter

original: concerning a previous birth of yakṣa Kumbhīra
analyzed: concerning a previous birth of yakṣa kumbhīra
translated: concerning a previous birth of the yaksha Kumbhira

original: bhūtapūrvaṃ bhikṣavo vārāṇasyāṃ nagaryāṃ brahmadatto nāma rājā rājyaṃ kārayati ṛddhaṃ ca sphītaṃ ca kṣemaṃ ca subhikṣaṃ ca ākīrṇabahujanamanuṣyaṃ
analyzed: bhūta pūrvam bhikṣavaḥ vārāṇasyām nagaryām brahmadattaḥ nāma rājā rājyam kārayati ṛddham ca sphītam ca kṣemam ca subhikṣam ca ākīrṇa bahu jana manuṣyam
translated: Monks, in the past, in the city of Varanasi, a king named Brahmadatta ruled a kingdom that was prosperous, abundant, peaceful, and well-populated, with an abundance of food and people.

original: tena khalu samayena vārāṇasyāṃ nagaryāṃ nātidūre anyatarasminn āśramapade mūlapuṣpaphalasalilasaṃpanne nānāvihaganikūjite ṛṣiḥ prativasati /
analyzed: tena khalu samayena vārāṇasyām nagaryām na atidūre anyatarasmin āśrama pade mūla puṣpa phala salila saṃpanne nānā vihaga nikūjite ṛṣiḥ prativasati
translated: At that time, not far from the city of Vārāṇasī, in an ashram rich with roots, flowers, fruits, and water, with the songs of various birds, a sage was living.

analyzed: kaṣṭa tapāḥ phala mūla ambu bhakṣaḥ ajina valkala vāsāḥ
translated: He was practicing severe austerities, subsisting on fruits, roots, and water, wearing garments of bark and antelope skin.

original: tasya cāśramapadasya sāmantakena mṛgalubdhako mṛgān praghātya praghātya jīvikāṃ kalpayati /
analyzed: tasya ca āśrama padasya sāmantakena mṛga lubdhakaḥ mṛgān praghātya praghātya jīvikām kalpayati
translated: Near his ashram, a hunter made a living by killing deer one by one.

original: sa tasya ṛṣeḥ kālena kālam upasaṃkrāmati /
analyzed: sa tasya ṛṣeḥ kālena kālam upasaṃkrāmati
translated: He would come to visit the sage from time to time.

original: tasyāsau ṛṣiḥ śrāntasya mūlaphalair upasaṃhāraṃ karoti /
analyzed: tasya asau ṛṣiḥ śrāntasya mūla phalaiḥ upasaṃhāram karoti
translated: The sage would offer him roots and fruits when he was tired.

original: apy evāyaṃ lubdhako matsarī SBV II
analyzed: api eva ayam lubdhakaḥ matsarī
translated: The sage thought, This hunter is jealous.

analyzed: samīpa nivāsinaḥ mṛgān na praghātayet iti
translated: If he stays nearby, he will kill the deer.

analyzed: tayoḥ parasparam pitṛ putra iti saṃjñā samutpannā
translated: Thus, a mutual understanding arose between them as father and son.

analyzed: lubdhakaḥ ṛṣim pitṛ vādena samudācarati
translated: The hunter addressed the sage with the words father.

analyzed: ṛṣiḥ api lubdhakam putra vādena
translated: The sage also addressed the hunter with the words son.

original: yāvad apareṇa samayena rājā brahmadattaḥ kālyam evotthāya mṛgavadhāya nirgataḥ /
analyzed: yāvat apareṇa samayena rājā brahmadattaḥ kālyam eva utthāya mṛga vadhāya nirgataḥ
translated: Later, King Brahmadatta rose early in the morning and went out to hunt deer.

original: tena mṛgaḥ śaraparamparayā tāḍitaḥ utpatitaḥ taya ṛṣer āśramapadaṃ praviṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: tena mṛgaḥ śara paramparayā tāḍitaḥ utpatitaḥ ṛṣeḥ āśrama padam praviṣṭaḥ
translated: The deer, struck by a series of arrows, flew up and entered the sage's hermitage.

original: tatrāpi rājñā nārācena marmaṇi tāḍitaḥ kālagataḥ /
analyzed: tatra api rājñā nārācena marmaṇi tāḍitaḥ kālagataḥ
translated: There too, the king struck him in a vital spot with an iron arrow and he died.

analyzed: saḥ ṛṣiḥ krodha paryavasthitaḥ kathayati
translated: The sage, overcome with anger, said:

original: kalirājas tvaṃ durācāro yena me śaraṇopagato mṛgaḥ praghātitaḥ iti /
analyzed: kali rājaḥ tvam durācāraḥ yena me śaraṇa upagataḥ mṛgaḥ praghātitaḥ iti
translated: You are a wicked king, Kali, who has killed the deer that came to me for refuge.

original: evam ukte sa rājā dveṣaparyavasthānaniviṣṭabuddhir amātyānāṃ kathayati /
analyzed: evam ukte sa rājā dveṣa paryavasthāna niviṣṭa buddhiḥ amātyānām kathayati
translated: When this was said, the king, his mind fixed on the state of hatred, said to his ministers:

original: bhavanto yo rājānaṃ kṣatriyaṃ mūrdhābhiṣiktaṃ paribhāṣate tasya ko daṇḍaḥ iti /
analyzed: bhavantaḥ yaḥ rājānam kṣatriyam mūrdhābhiṣiktam paribhāṣate tasya kaḥ daṇḍaḥ iti
translated: Gentlemen, what is the punishment for one who reviles a king, a kshatriya anointed on the head?

analyzed: amātyāḥ kathayanti
translated: The ministers said:

analyzed: vadhaḥ daṇḍaḥ iti
translated: The punishment is death.

analyzed: rājā kathayati
translated: The king said:

original: yady evaṃ parityakto me ayam ṛṣiḥ /
analyzed: yadi evam parityaktaḥ me ayam ṛṣiḥ
translated: If that is so, then this sage is abandoned by me.

analyzed: amātyāḥ ṛṣim praghātayitum ārabdhāḥ
translated: The ministers began to kill the sage.

original: daivāt sa lubdhakas tasya ṛṣeḥ sakāśam āgataḥ /
analyzed: daivāt sa lubdhakaḥ tasya ṛṣeḥ sakāśam āgataḥ
translated: By chance, that hunter came to the sage.

analyzed: āgataḥ eva sa saṃlakṣayati
translated: As soon as he arrived, he thought:

original: mama jīvataḥ katham ṛṣiḥ praghātyate iti /
analyzed: mama jīvataḥ katham ṛṣiḥ praghātyate iti
translated: How can the sage be killed while I am alive?

analyzed: sa yoddhum ārabdhaḥ
translated: He started to fight.

analyzed: ṛṣiḥ niṣpalāyitaḥ
translated: The sage ran away.

analyzed: sa mahatā balakāyena praghātitaḥ
translated: He was killed by a large force.

analyzed: bhagavān āha
translated: The Blessed One said:

original: kiṃ manyadhve bhikṣavo yo 'sau ṛṣir aham eva saḥ tena kālena tena samayena /
analyzed: kim manyadhve bhikṣavaḥ yaḥ sau ṛṣiḥ aham eva saḥ tena kālena tena samayena
translated: Monks, what do you think? At that time, on that occasion, I was that sage.

original: yo 'sau lubdhakaḥ eṣa eva sa kumbhīrayakṣaḥ tena kālena tena samayena /🔽tadāpy anena mamārthāya ātmā parityaktaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ sau lubdhakaḥ eṣaḥ eva sa kumbhīrayakṣaḥ tena kālena tena samayena  tadā api anena mama arthāya ātmā parityaktaḥ
translated: At that time, on that occasion, this very one was the hunter.🔽Even then, for my sake, he gave up his life.

original: etarhy apy anena mamārthāya ātmā parityaktaḥ iti
analyzed: etarhi api anena mama arthāya ātmā parityaktaḥ iti
translated: Now also, for my sake, he gave up his life.

original: Jīvaka prescribes a very rare substance called gośīrṣacandana in order to stop the hemorrhage at the foot of the Buddha🔽bhagavataḥ pāṣāṇaśarkarayā A
analyzed: jīvaka prescribes a very rare substance called gośīrṣacandana in ordra to stop the hemorrhage at the foot of the buddha  bhagavataḥ pāṣāṇa śarkarayā
translated: Jīvaka prescribes a very rare substance called gośīrṣacandana in order to stop the bleeding at the foot of the Buddha

analyzed: pādaḥ kṣataḥ
translated: The Blessed One's foot was cut by a stone splinter.

analyzed: rudhiram pragharati eva na avatiṣṭhate
translated: The bleeding continued and did not stop.

original: jīvako vaidyarājo bhagavato rujāvalokakaḥ trikālam upasaṃkrāmati /
analyzed: jīvakaḥ vaidya rājaḥ bhagavataḥ rujā avalokakaḥ tri kālam upasaṃkrāmati
translated: Jīvaka, the king of physicians, who was looking after the Blessed One's illness, visited him three times a day.

original: rājagṛhanivāsī śrāddho janakāyaḥ nānādeśabhyāgatāś ca samyagdarśanasaṃpannāḥ dhaninaḥ śreṣṭhinaḥ sārthavāhāḥ /
analyzed: rājagṛha nivāsī śrāddhaḥ jana kāyaḥ nānā deśa bhyāgatāḥ ca samyak darśana saṃpannāḥ dhaninaḥ śreṣṭhinaḥ sārthavāhāḥ
translated: The faithful people living in Rājagṛha and those who had come from various countries, endowed with right view, wealthy, leading merchants, and caravan leaders

analyzed: tatra kecid kathayati
translated: Among them, some said:

original: jīvaka idam atra bhaiṣajyaṃ śobhanam iti /
analyzed: jīvakaḥ idam atra bhaiṣajyam śobhanam iti
translated: Jīvaka said, This medicine is good for this.

analyzed: anye kathayanti
translated: Others said,

analyzed: idam śobhanam iti
translated: This is good.

analyzed: jīvakaḥ vaidya rājaḥ kathayati
translated: Jīvaka, the king of physicians, said,

analyzed: asti atra sadyas praśamanam bhaiṣajyam
translated: There is a medicine here that quickly alleviates it,

analyzed: kim tu tat durlabham
translated: but it is difficult to obtain.

analyzed: āyuṣmān ānanda kathayati
translated: The Venerable Ānanda said,

analyzed: jīvaka kim tat
translated: Jīvaka, what is it?

analyzed: sa kathayati
translated: He said,

original: gośīrṣacandanaṃ /🔽tena khalu samayena goṣīrṣacandanasya prāptir eva samucchinnā /
analyzed: tena khalu samayena goṣīrṣa candanasya prāptiḥ eva samucchinnā
translated: Gośīrṣa sandalwood.🔽At that time, the supply of Gośīrṣa sandalwood had been completely cut off.

original: yāvad anyatamena vaṇijā gośīrṣacandanam ātyayikaṃ sthāpitam /
analyzed: yāvat anyatamena vaṇijā gośīrṣa candanam ātyayikam sthāpitam
translated: Then a certain merchant had put up for sale Gośīrṣa sandalwood.

original: ayaṃ rājā ajātaśatruś caṇḍo rabhasaḥ karkaśaḥ /
analyzed: ayam rājā ajātaśatruḥ caṇḍaḥ rabhasaḥ karkaśaḥ
translated: This King Ajātaśatru is fierce, impetuous, and harsh.

original: yady asya daivād gośīrṣacandanena prayojanaṃ bhavati SBV II
analyzed: yadi asya daivāt gośīrṣa candanena prayojanam bhavati
translated: If by chance he needs Gośīrṣa sandalwood,

analyzed: niyatam śiraḥ chedam api karoti
translated: it is certain that because of its unavailability he will even have my head cut off.

original: yasmād ahaṃ kālānukālaṃ gośīrṣacandanavikrayaṃ kṛtavān iti /
analyzed: yasmāt aham kāla anukālam gośīrṣa candana vikrayam kṛtavān iti
translated: Because I have been selling Gośīrṣa sandalwood from time to time.

original: tena śrutaṃ yathā jīvakena vaidyarājena bhagavato rujāpraśamanaṃ gośīrṣacandanam upadiṣṭam iti /
analyzed: tena śrutam yathā jīvakena vaidya rājena bhagavataḥ rujā praśamanam gośīrṣa candanam upadiṣṭam iti
translated: He heard that Jīvaka, the king of physicians, had advised the Blessed One to use Gośīrṣa sandalwood to alleviate his illness.

analyzed: sa saṃlakṣayati
translated: He thought,

analyzed: ayam ajātaśatruḥ devadatta vigrāhitaḥ bhagavati abhiniviṣṭa buddhiḥ
translated: This Ajātaśatru, influenced by Devadatta, has a mind fixed on the Blessed One.

original: yady ahaṃ bhagavato gośīrṣacandanaṃ pradāsyāmi sthānam etad vidyate yad anarthaṃ kariṣyati iti /
analyzed: yadi aham bhagavataḥ gośīrṣa candanam pradāsyāmi sthānam etat vidyate yat anartham kariṣyati iti
translated: If I were to give the Blessed One the gośīrṣa sandalwood, it is possible that he would do something harmful.

analyzed: punar saṃlakṣayati
translated: He thought again:

analyzed: bhagavān deva manuṣya pūjitaḥ
translated: The Blessed One is worshipped by gods and humans.

analyzed: yadi prāṇa viyogaḥ bhavati
translated: If it leads to the loss of his life for his sake,

analyzed: bhavati eva
translated: it will happen.

original: yannv ahaṃ bhagavato gośīrṣacandanaṃ prayaccheyam iti /
analyzed: yat nu aham bhagavataḥ gośīrṣa candanam prayaccheyam iti
translated: So let me offer the gośīrṣa sandalwood to the Blessed One.

original: sa gośīrṣacandanam ādāya bhagavatsakāśam upasaṃkrāntaḥ pādayor nipatya kathayati /
analyzed: sa gośīrṣa candanam ādāya bhagavat sakāśam upasaṃkrāntaḥ pādayoḥ nipatya kathayati
translated: Taking the gośīrṣa sandalwood, he approached the Blessed One, fell at his feet, and said:

original: bhagavann upalabdhaṃ mayā bhagavato gośīrṣacandanena prayojanam iti /
analyzed: bhagavan upalabdham mayā bhagavataḥ gośīrṣa candanena prayojanam iti
translated: Blessed One, I have understood that the Blessed One has a use for the gośīrṣa sandalwood.

original: idaṃ tat pratigṛhṇātu bhagavān anukampām upādāya iti /
analyzed: idam tat pratigṛhṇātu bhagavān anukampām upādāya iti
translated: May the Blessed One accept this out of compassion.

analyzed: tatra bhagavān āyuṣmantam ānandam āmantrayate
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the venerable Ānanda:

original: pratigṛhṇīṣva ānanda asya mahātmanaḥ sakāśād gośīrṣacandanam iti /
analyzed: pratigṛhṇīṣva ānanda asya mahātmanaḥ sakāśāt gośīrṣa candanam iti
translated: Accept this gośīrṣa sandalwood from this great being, Ānanda.

analyzed: āyuṣmatā ānandena pratigṛhītam
translated: It was accepted by the venerable Ānanda.

original: tato 'sau vaṇik prītiprāmodyajātaḥ bhagavataḥ pādau śirasā vanditvā bhagavato 'ntikāt prakrāntaḥ
analyzed: tatas sau vaṇij prīti prāmodya jātaḥ bhagavataḥ pādau śirasā vanditvā bhagavataḥ ntikāt prakrāntaḥ
translated: Then the merchant, filled with joy and delight, bowed his head at the feet of the Blessed One and departed from the presence of the Blessed One.

analyzed: atha bhagavān vismitam akārṣīt
translated: Then the Blessed One smiled.

original: dharmatā khalu yasmin samaye buddhā bhagavantaḥ smitaṃ prāviṣkurvanti tasmin samaye nīlapītalohitāvadātāḥ arciṣaḥ mukhān niścarya kāścid adhastād
analyzed: dharmatā khalu yasmin samaye buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ smitam prāviṣkurvanti tasmin samaye nīla pīta lohita avadātāḥ arciṣaḥ mukhāt niścarya kāścid adhastāt
translated: It is a natural law that when the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, smile, rays of blue, yellow, red, and white colors issue forth from their mouths. Some go downward

analyzed: kāścid upariṣṭāt gacchanti
translated: and some go upward.

original: yā adhastād gacchanti tāḥ sañjīvaṃ kālasūtraṃ saṅghātaṃ rauravaṃ mahārauravaṃ tāpanaṃ
analyzed: yāḥ adhastāt gacchanti tāḥ sañjīvam kālasūtram saṅghātam rauravam mahārauravam tāpanam
translated: Those that go downward go to Saṃjīva, Kālasūtra, Saṃghata, Raurava, Mahāraurava, Tapana,

original: pratāpanam avīcim arbudaṃ nirarbudam aṭaṭaṃ hahavaṃ huhuvam utpalaṃ padmaṃ mahāpadmaṃ🔽narakaṃ gatvā ye uṣṇanarakās teṣu śītībhūtvā nipatanti /
analyzed: pratāpanam avīcim arbudam nirarbudam aṭaṭam hahavam huhuvam utpalam padmam mahāpadmam  narakam gatvā ye uṣṇa narakāḥ teṣu śītībhūtvā nipatanti
translated: Pratāpana, Avīci, Arbuda, Nirarbuda, Aṭaṭa, Hahava, Huhuva, Utpala, Padma, and Mahāpadma🔽hells, and having gone there, they fall as cool water into those that are hot hells.

analyzed: ye śīta narakāḥ teṣu uṣṇībhūtvā nipatanti
translated: And they fall as hot water into those that are cold hells.

analyzed: tena teṣām satvānām kāraṇā viśeṣāḥ pratiprasrabhyante
translated: By that, the particular causes of those beings are calmed.

analyzed: teṣām evam bhavati
translated: They think thus:🔽What is this?

original: kiṃ nu vayaṃ bhavantaḥ itaś cyutāḥ āhosvid anyatropapannāḥ iti /
analyzed: kim nu vayam bhavantaḥ itas cyutāḥ āhosvit anyatra upapannāḥ iti
translated: What is this? Are we fallen from here, or born elsewhere?

analyzed: teṣām prasāda saṃjanana artham bhagavān nirmitam visarjayati
translated: In order to generate faith in them, the Blessed One sends forth a magical creation.

analyzed: teṣām nirmitam dṛṣṭvā evam bhavati
translated: Seeing the magical creation, they think thus:

original: na haiva vayaṃ bhavantaḥ itaś cyutāḥ /
analyzed: na ha eva vayam bhavantaḥ itas cyutāḥ
translated: Surely, Sirs, we have not fallen from here,

analyzed: na api anyatra upapannāḥ
translated: nor have we been born elsewhere.

analyzed: api tu ayam apūrva darśanaḥ satvaḥ
translated: But this is a being of an unprecedented appearance.

original: asya anubhāvena asmākaṃ kāraṇāviśeṣāḥ pratiprasrabdhāḥ iti /
analyzed: asya anubhāvena asmākam kāraṇā viśeṣāḥ pratiprasrabdhāḥ iti
translated: By his power, our particular causes of suffering have ceased.

analyzed: te nirmite cittam abhiprasādya
translated: Having generated faith in the magical creation,

analyzed: tat naraka vedanīyam karma kṣapayitvā deva manuṣyeṣu pratisandhim gṛhṇanti yatra satyānām bhājana bhūtāḥ bhavanti
translated: they exhaust that karma to be experienced in hell, and take rebirth among gods and humans, where they become vessels for the truths.

analyzed: yāḥ upariṣṭāt gacchanti tāḥ cāturmahārājikān trayastriṃśān yāmān tuṣitān nirmāṇa ratīn
translated: Those that go upwards go to the Caturmaharajakas, the Trayastrimsas, the Yamas, the Tusitas, the Nirmanaratis,

analyzed: paranirmitavaśavartinaḥ brahmakāyikān brahmapurohitān mahābrahmaṇaḥ parīttābhān apramāṇābhān
translated: the Paranirmitavasavartins, the Brahmakayikas, the Brahmapurohitas, the Mahabrahmans, the Parittas, the Apramanas,🔽the Abhasvaras,

analyzed: ābhāsvarān parīttaśubhān apramāṇaśubhān śubhakṛtsnān anabhrakān puṇyaprasavān bṛhatphalān
translated: Having gone to the Abhasvaras, Parittashubhas, Apramanashubhas, Shubhakrishnas, Anabhrakas, Punyaprasavas, Brihatphalas,

original: abṛhān atapān sudṛśān sudarśanān akaniṣṭhān devān gatvā anityaṃ duḥkhaṃ śūnyam anātmā ity udghoṣayanti /
analyzed: abṛhān atapān sudṛśān sudarśanān akaniṣṭhān devān gatvā anityam duḥkham śūnyam anātmā iti udghoṣayanti
translated: Avaras, Atapans, Sudarishanas, Sudarshanas, and Akanishtha gods, they proclaim: Impermanent, suffering, empty, non-self.

analyzed: gāthā dvayam ca bhāṣante
translated: And they speak two verses:

analyzed: ārabhadhvam niṣkrāmata yujyadhvam buddha śāsane
translated: Arise, go forth, apply yourselves to the Buddha's teaching.

analyzed: dhunīta mṛtyunaḥ sainyam naḍa āgāram iva kuñjaraḥ

analyzed: yaḥ hi asmin dharma vinaye apramattaḥ cariṣyati
translated: He who will practice heedful in this Dharma and Vinaya,

analyzed: prahāya jāti saṃsāram duḥkhasya antam kariṣyati iti
translated: Having abandoned the cycle of birth, will make an end to suffering.

original: atha tā arciṣas trisahasramahāsahasraṃ lokadhātum anvāhiṇḍya bhagavantam eva pṛṣṭhataḥ pṛṣṭhataḥ samanugacchanti /
analyzed: atha tāḥ arciṣaḥ tri sahasra mahā sahasram lokadhātum anvāhiṇḍya bhagavantam eva pṛṣṭhatas pṛṣṭhatas samanugacchanti
translated: Then those flames, having circled the great trichiliocosm, follow closely behind the Blessed One.

original: tad yadi bhagavān atītaṃ karma vyākartukāmo bhavati /
analyzed: tat yadi bhagavān atītam karma vyākartu kāmaḥ bhavati
translated: If the Blessed One wishes to explain an action in the past,

analyzed: bhagavataḥ pṛṣṭhatas ntardhīyante
translated: they disappear behind the Blessed One.

analyzed: anāgatam vyākartu kāmaḥ bhavati
translated: If he wishes to explain an action in the future,

analyzed: purastāt antardhīyante
translated: they disappear in front.

translated: If he wishes to prophesy rebirth in hell, they disappear into the soles of his feet.🔽If he wishes to prophesy rebirth as an animal, they disappear into his heels.

analyzed: preta upapattim vyākartu kāmaḥ bhavati pādāṅguṣṭhe antardhīyante
translated: If he wishes to prophesy rebirth as a hungry ghost, they disappear into his big toes.

translated: If he wishes to prophesy human rebirth, they disappear into his knees.🔽If he wishes to prophesy the status of a powerful wheel-turning king, they disappear into the palm of his left hand.

original: cakravartirājyaṃ vyākartukāmo bhavati dakṣiṇe karatale antardhīyante /
analyzed: cakravarti rājyam vyākartu kāmaḥ bhavati dakṣiṇe kara tale antardhīyante

original: devopapattiṃ vyākartukāmo bhavati nābhyām antardhīyante /🔽śrāvakabodhiṃ vyākartukāmo bhavati āsye 'ntardhīyante /🔽pratyekabodhiṃ vyākartukāmo bhavati ūrṇāyām antardhīyante /

translated: If he wishes to prophesy rebirth as a god, they disappear into his navel.🔽If he wishes to prophesy the enlightenment of a disciple, they disappear into his mouth.🔽If he wishes to prophesy individual enlightenment, they disappear into his tuft of hair between the eyebrows.

original: anuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhiṃ vyākartukāmo bhavati uṣṇīṣe antardhīyante
analyzed: anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim vyākartu kāmaḥ bhavati uṣṇīṣe antardhīyante
translated: If he wishes to prophesy unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, they disappear into his ushnisha.

original: atha tā arciṣo bhagavantaṃ triḥ pradakṣiṇīkṛtya bhagavata ūrṇāyām antarhitāḥ /

analyzed: atha āyuṣmān ānandaḥ kṛta kara puṭaḥ bhagavantam papraccha  nānāvidhaḥ raṅga sahasra citraḥ

analyzed: avabhāsitāḥ yena diśaḥ samantāt

analyzed: divākareṇa udayatā yathā eva

analyzed: gāthāḥ ca bhāṣate  vigata udbhavā dainya mada prahīṇā
translated: And he spoke these verses:🔽The Buddhas, who have abandoned arising, dejection, and pride,

analyzed: buddhāḥ jagati uttama hetu bhūtāḥ  na akāraṇam śaṅkha mṛṇāla gauram
translated: are the supreme cause in the world.

analyzed: smitam upadarśayanti jināḥ jita arayaḥ
translated: The Victorious Ones, the Conquerors, do not display a smile that is the color of a conch or lotus stalk without a reason.

analyzed: tad kālam svayam adhigamya dhīra buddhyā
translated: At that time, having understood by oneself with firm intelligence,

analyzed: dhīrābhiḥ muni vṛṣa vāgbhiḥ uttamābhiḥ

analyzed: utpannam vyapanaya saṃśayam śubhābhiḥ  lavaṇajala adrirāja dhairyāḥ
translated: remove the doubt that has arisen with your auspicious words.🔽The Fully Enlightened Ones, the Lords, who are unshakable like the salty ocean and the king of mountains,

analyzed: saṃbuddhāḥ smitam upadarśayanti nāthāḥ
translated: do not display a smile without a reason.

analyzed: yasya arthe smitam upadarśayanti dhīrāḥ
translated: For whose sake do the wise ones display a smile?

original: taṃ śrotuṃ samabhilaṣanti te janaughāḥ // iti
analyzed: tam śrotum samabhilaṣanti te jana oghāḥ iti

translated: The Blessed One said:

analyzed: na a hetu pratyayam ānanda tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ smitam prāviṣkurvanti
translated: Ananda, Tathagatas, Arhats, Perfectly Awakened Ones do not smile without a cause or condition.

translated: Ananda, have you seen that merchant

analyzed: yena tathāgatasya cittam abhiprasādya gośīrṣa candanam

analyzed: dattam dṛṣṭaḥ bhadanta

analyzed: ayam asya deya dharmaḥ yaḥ mama antike citta prasādaḥ
translated: This is his Dharma offering, the faith in me

analyzed: and jīvaka prescribes the milk of a young woman
translated: And Jīvaka prescribes the milk of a young woman

analyzed: na avatiṣṭhate

analyzed: jīvakaḥ kathayati

analyzed: kutas punar anyasya dāsyati

analyzed: na kevalam ayam ādīnavaḥ
translated: This is not only a disadvantage.

analyzed: ayam aparaḥ
translated: This is another.

analyzed: devadattaḥ bhagavataḥ dīrgharātram pratyarthikaḥ pratyamitraḥ
translated: Devadatta has been the Blessed One's enemy for a long time.

original: tadvigrāhitaś ca rājā ajātaśatruḥ devadattapakṣyāś ca kokālikakhaṇḍadravyakaṭamorakatiṣyasamudradattāḥ /
analyzed: tad vigrāhitaḥ ca rājā ajātaśatruḥ devadatta pakṣyāḥ ca kokālika khaṇḍa dravya kaṭa moraka tiṣya samudra dattāḥ
translated: And instigated by him, King Ajātaśatru, Devadatta's supporters Kokālika, Khaṇḍa, Dhraṣṭa, Mora, and Samudradatta,

analyzed: ete mām jīvitāt vyaparopayiṣyanti iti
translated: they will deprive me of life.

analyzed: punar saṃlakṣayati
translated: She thought again:

analyzed: kāmam sva prāṇa viyogaḥ putra viyogaḥ ca
translated: Better to be separated from my own life and my son,

original: na tu devamanuṣyapūjitasya buddhasya bhagavataḥ vyādhiduḥkhavedanānubhavanaṃ yena sarva eva rājagṛhanivāsī janakāyaḥ samākulaḥ /

translated: but not to experience the suffering of illness of the Blessed Buddha, worshipped by gods and humans, by which the entire population of Rājagṛha is agitated.

original: yannv ahaṃ kṣīram ādāya gaccheyam iti /
analyzed: yat nu aham kṣīram ādāya gaccheyam iti
translated: So let me go, taking milk.

translated: She, having faith in the Blessed One, having milked milk into a new vessel, approached the Blessed One.

original: upasaṃkramya bhagavataḥ pādau śirasā vanditvā bhagavantam idam avocat /
analyzed: upasaṃkramya bhagavataḥ pādau śirasā vanditvā bhagavantam idam avocat

analyzed: upalabdham mayā bhadanta jīvakena bhagavataḥ kanyā kṣīram upadiṣṭam iti
translated: Venerable Sir, I have obtained the Blessed One's daughter's milk, as instructed by Jīvaka.

original: tad idaṃ kanyākṣīraṃ pragṛhyatāṃ mamānugrahāya iti /
analyzed: tat idam kanyā kṣīram pragṛhyatām mama anugrahāya iti
translated: Please accept this daughter's milk for my benefit.

analyzed: tatra bhagavān āyuṣmantam ānandam āmantrayate
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the venerable Ānanda:

original: bhadrāśayā iyam ānanda dārikā /🔽asyā sakāśād gṛhāṇa kṣīram iti /
analyzed: bhadrāśayā iyam ānanda dārikā  asyāḥ sakāśāt gṛhāṇa kṣīram iti
translated: Ānanda, this girl has a good intention.🔽Take the milk from her.

analyzed: tena pratigṛhītam kṣīram
translated: He accepted the milk.

original: sā bhagavataḥ pādau śirasā vanditvā bhagavato 'ntikāt prakrāntā
analyzed: sā bhagavataḥ pādau śirasā vanditvā bhagavataḥ ntikāt prakrāntā
translated: She bowed her head at the feet of the Blessed One and departed from the presence of the Blessed One.

analyzed: atha bhagavān vismitam akārṣīt
translated: Then the Blessed One was amazed.

translated: It is a natural law that when the Blessed Buddhas smile, rays of blue, yellow, red, and white light issue forth from their mouths, some going downward

analyzed: kāścid upariṣṭāt gacchanti
translated: and some going upward.

original: yā adhastād gacchanti tāḥ sañjīvaṃ kālasūtraṃ saṅghātaṃ rauravaṃ mahārauravaṃ tāpanaṃ
analyzed: yāḥ adhastāt gacchanti tāḥ sañjīvam kālasūtram saṅghātam rauravam mahārauravam tāpanam
translated: Those that go downward go to Saṃjīva, Kālasūtra, Saṃghata, Raurava, Mahāraurava, Tapana,

original: pratāpanam avīcim arbudaṃ nirarbudam aṭaṭaṃ hahavaṃ huhuvam utpalaṃ padmaṃ mahāpadmaṃ🔽narakaṃ gatvā ye uṣṇanarakās teṣu śītībhūtvā nipatanti /
analyzed: pratāpanam avīcim arbudam nirarbudam aṭaṭam hahavam huhuvam utpalam padmam mahāpadmam  narakam gatvā ye uṣṇa narakāḥ teṣu śītībhūtvā nipatanti
translated: The hot hells are Tapana, Pratāpana, Saṃjīva, Kālasūtra, Saṃghāta, Raurava, Mahāraurava, Tapana, Pratāpana.🔽Having gone to the hells, they fall into the hot hells as cool water.

analyzed: ye śīta narakāḥ teṣu uṣṇībhūtvā nipatanti
translated: In the cold hells, they fall as hot water.

analyzed: tena teṣām satvānām kāraṇā viśeṣāḥ pratiprasrabhyante
translated: By that, the specific causes of those beings are calmed.

analyzed: teṣām evam bhavati
translated: They think like this:

original: kiṃ nu vayaṃ bhavantaḥ itaś cyutāḥ āhosvid anyatropapannāḥ iti /

translated: Are we fallen from here, or are we reborn elsewhere?

analyzed: teṣām prasāda saṃjanana artham bhagavān nirmitam visarjayati
translated: In order to generate faith in them, the Blessed One sends forth a magical creation.

analyzed: teṣām nirmitam dṛṣṭvā evam bhavati
translated: Having seen the magical creation, they think like this:

original: na haiva vayaṃ bhavantaḥ itaś cyutāḥ /
analyzed: na ha eva vayam bhavantaḥ itas cyutāḥ
translated: Indeed, we are not fallen from here,

analyzed: na api anyatra upapannāḥ
translated: nor are we reborn elsewhere.

analyzed: etarhi api aham anena satya upayācanena svasthīkṛtaḥ

analyzed: nirvāṇa mārgaḥ ca mayā upalabdhaḥ
translated: and the path to nirvana has been discovered by me.

analyzed: tvad āśrayāt ca āptam apeta doṣam
translated: And by relying on you, I have attained today,

analyzed: mayā adya śuddham su viśuddha cakṣuḥ
translated: with pure and very pure eyes, free from faults,

analyzed: prāptam ca śāntam padam ārya kāntam
translated: and have attained the peaceful state loved by the noble ones.

analyzed: tīrṇaḥ ca duḥkha arṇava pāram asmi
translated: And I have crossed to the other shore of the ocean of suffering.

analyzed: jagati daitya nara amara pūjitam
translated: You are worshipped in the world by demons, humans, and gods,

analyzed: vigata janma jarā maraṇa āmayam
translated: Free from birth, old age, death, and disease.

analyzed: bhava sahasra su durlabha darśanam
translated: It is extremely difficult to see you even in a thousand existences.

analyzed: saphalam adya mune tava darśanam
translated: Today, Sage, seeing you has been fruitful.

original: avanamya tataḥ pralambahāraḥ🔽caraṇau dvāv abhivandya jātaharṣaḥ / SBV II
analyzed: avanamya tatas pralamba hāraḥ  caraṇau dvau abhivandya jāta harṣaḥ
translated: Then, with a long necklace hanging down,

analyzed: parigamya ca dakṣiṇam jita arim
translated: he joyfully bowed his head to the feet of the Victorious One,🔽and circumambulated the Victorious One clockwise.

original: suralokābhimukho divaṃ jagāma //🔽atha nāgapūrvī devaputro vaṇig iva labdhalābhaḥ sasyasaṃpanna iva kārṣakaḥ śūra iva
analyzed: sura loka abhimukhaḥ divam jagāma  atha nāgapūrvī deva putraḥ vaṇij iva labdha lābhaḥ sasya saṃpannaḥ iva kārṣakaḥ śūraḥ iva
translated: Then he went to the heavens, to the world of the gods.

original: jitasaṃgrāmaḥ sarvarogaparimukta ivāturo yayā vibhūtyā bhagavatsakāśam upasaṃkrāntaḥ
analyzed: jita saṃgrāmaḥ sarva roga parimuktaḥ iva āturaḥ yayā vibhūtyā bhagavat sakāśam upasaṃkrāntaḥ
translated: Then the god Nāga-pūrva, like a merchant who has gained profit, like a farmer with a good harvest, like a hero who has won a battle, like a patient completely cured of all diseases, with the same splendor with which he had approached the Blessed One,

analyzed: tayā eva vibhūtyā sva bhavanam gataḥ
translated: he went to his own abode.

original: bhikṣavaḥ pūrvarātrāpararātraṃ jāgarikānuyogam anuyuktā viharanti /🔽tair dṛṣṭo bhagavato 'ntike udāro 'vabhāsaḥ /
analyzed: bhikṣavaḥ pūrvarātra apararātram jāgarika anuyogam anuyuktāḥ viharanti  taiḥ dṛṣṭaḥ bhagavataḥ ntike udāraḥ vabhāsaḥ
translated: Monks, they dwell engaged in the practice of staying awake during the first and last parts of the night.🔽By them a great light was seen in the presence of the Blessed One.

analyzed: yam dṛṣṭvā bhagavantam papracchuḥ
translated: Having seen it, they asked the Blessed One.

original: kiṃ bhagavan imāṃ rātriṃ bhagavantaṃ darśanāya brahmā sabhāṃpatiḥ śakro devendraḥ catvāro lokapālā upasaṃkrāntāḥ bhagavān āha /
analyzed: kim bhagavan imām rātrim bhagavantam darśanāya brahmā sabhāṃpatiḥ śakraḥ deva indraḥ catvāraḥ lokapālāḥ upasaṃkrāntāḥ bhagavān āha
translated: What, Blessed One, did Brahmā, the lord of the assembly, Śakra, lord of the gods, and the four world guardians come to see the Blessed One in the night? The Blessed One said:

original: na bhikṣavo brahmā sabhāṃpatiḥ na śakro devānām indraḥ nāpi catvāro lokapālāḥ māṃ darśanāyopasaṃkrāntāḥ /
analyzed: na bhikṣavaḥ brahmā sabhāṃpatiḥ na śakraḥ devānām indraḥ na api catvāraḥ lokapālāḥ mām darśanāya upasaṃkrāntāḥ
translated: Monks, it was not Brahmā, the lord of the assembly, nor Śakra, lord of the gods, nor the four world guardians who came to see me.

original: api tu yuṣmābhir bhikṣavaḥ sa dhanapālo hastināgaḥ /
analyzed: api tu yuṣmābhiḥ bhikṣavaḥ sa dhanapālaḥ hasti nāgaḥ
translated: But, monks, it was that very Dhanapaāla, the elephant-king.

original: tāvac caṇḍaḥ tāvad rabhaso yas tathāgatasya vadhāya parākrāntaḥ dṛṣṭo bhadanta /🔽mayā vinītaḥ sa mamāntike cittam abhiprasādya kālagataḥ cāturmahārājijeṣu deveṣūpapannaḥ /
analyzed: tāvat caṇḍaḥ tāvat rabhasaḥ yaḥ tathāgatasya vadhāya parākrāntaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ bhadanta  mayā vinītaḥ sa mama antike cittam abhiprasādya kālagataḥ cāturmahārājijeṣu deveṣu upapannaḥ
translated: He was so fierce, so violent, that he was about to kill the Tathāgata. Yes, Bhadanta, they said.🔽I tamed him. Having generated faith in me, he died and was reborn among the gods of the Four Great Kings.

analyzed: saḥ imām rātrim mad sakāśam upasaṃkrāntaḥ
translated: He came to me in the night.

analyzed: tasya mayā dharmaḥ deśitaḥ
translated: I taught him the Dharma.

analyzed: sa dṛṣṭa satyaḥ sva bhavanam gataḥ iti
translated: Having seen the truths, he went to his own abode.

original: bhikṣavaḥ saṃśayajātāḥ sarvasaṃśayacchettāraṃ buddhaṃ bhagavantaṃ papracchuḥ /
analyzed: bhikṣavaḥ saṃśaya jātāḥ sarva saṃśaya chettāram buddham bhagavantam papracchuḥ
translated: The monks, having doubts, asked the Blessed One, the Buddha, who removes all doubts:

original: kiṃ bhadanta dhanapālakena karma kṛtaṃ A
analyzed: kim bhadanta dhanapālakena karma kṛtam
translated: What deed did Dhanapaāla do, Bhadanta, that he was reborn among the gods of the Four Great Kings?

analyzed: yasya karmaṇaḥ vipākena tiryakṣu upapannaḥ
translated: By the ripening of which karma was he reborn as an animal?

original: kiṃ karma kṛtaṃ yena cāturmahārājikeṣu deveṣūpapannaḥ satyadarśanaṃ ca kṛtam iti /
analyzed: kim karma kṛtam yena cāturmahārājikeṣu deveṣu upapannaḥ satya darśanam ca kṛtam iti
translated: What karma did he create by which he was reborn among the gods of the Four Great Kings and attained the vision of the truth?

analyzed: bhagavān āha
translated: The Blessed One said:

original: dhanapālakenaiva hi bhikṣavaḥ karmāṇi kṛtāny upacitāni labdhasaṃbhārāṇi pariṇatapratyayāny oghavat pratyupasthitāny avaśyabhāvīni /
analyzed: dhanapālakena eva hi bhikṣavaḥ karmāṇi kṛtāni upacitāni labdha saṃbhārāṇi pariṇata pratyayāni oghavat pratyupasthitāni avaśya bhāvīni
translated: Monks, it is indeed Dhanapāla himself who has performed and accumulated these actions, which have accrued results, whose conditions are fulfilled, and which have appeared like an irresistible torrent, inevitably to be experienced.

original: dhanapālena karmāṇi kṛtāny upacitāni ko 'nyaḥ pratyanubhaviṣyati /
analyzed: dhanapālena karmāṇi kṛtāni upacitāni kaḥ nyaḥ pratyanubhaviṣyati
translated: By Dhanapāla actions have been performed and accumulated - who else will experience their results?

analyzed: na bhikṣavaḥ karmāṇi kṛtāni upacitāni
translated: Monks, actions that have been performed and accumulated

analyzed: pūrvavat yāvat phalanti khalu dehinām
translated: ... ripen for embodied beings, as explained before.

analyzed: dhanapālaka in a previous birth
translated: Dhanapāla in a previous birth

original: bhūtapūrvaṃ bhikṣavaḥ asminn eva bhadrake kalpe viṃśativarṣasahasrāyuṣi prajāyāṃ kāśyapo nāma śāstā loka udapādi /
analyzed: bhūta pūrvam bhikṣavaḥ asmin eva bhadrake kalpe viṃśati varṣa sahasra āyuṣi prajāyām kāśyapaḥ nāma śāstā loke udapādi
translated: Monks, in the past, in this very fortunate eon, when the lifespan of beings was twenty thousand years, a teacher named Kāśyapa appeared in the world,

original: vidyācaraṇasaṃpannaḥ sugato lokavid anuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā devamanuṣyāṇāṃ buddho bhagavān /
analyzed: vidyā caraṇa saṃpannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā deva manuṣyāṇām buddhaḥ bhagavān
translated: accomplished and fully enlightened, a blessed buddha, a teacher of gods and humans, renowned and exalted, an unsurpassed guide for those to be tamed, a teacher of gods and humans, a buddha, a blessed one.

original: sa vārāṇasīṃ nagarīm upaniśritya viharati ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve /
analyzed: sa vārāṇasīm nagarīm upaniśritya viharati ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve
translated: He was dwelling in the vicinity of the city of Vārāṇasī, in the Ṛṣivadana deer park.

original: tasya ca śāsane pravrajita āsīd vaiyāpṛtyakarah /
analyzed: tasya ca śāsane pravrajitaḥ āsīt vaiyāpṛtya karaḥ
translated: And in his teaching, he had gone forth as an attendant.

original: tatrānena kṣudrānukṣudreṣu śikṣāpadeṣu anādaraḥ SBV II
analyzed: tatra anena kṣudra anukṣudreṣu śikṣā padeṣu anādaraḥ
translated: There, he had disregarded the minor training rules.

analyzed: kṛtaḥ tasya karmaṇaḥ vipākena tiryakṣu upapannaḥ
translated: As a result of that karma, he was reborn as an animal.

original: yat tatrānena saṃghasya upasthānaṃ kṛtaṃ tasya karmaṇo vipākena annapānasya lābhī saṃvṛttaḥ /
analyzed: yat tatra anena saṃghasya upasthānam kṛtam tasya karmaṇaḥ vipākena anna pānasya lābhī saṃvṛttaḥ
translated: As a result of the service he had done to the Saṅgha there, he became one who obtained food and drink.

original: yan mamāntike cittam abhiprasādya kālagataḥ tena cāturmahārājikeṣu deveṣūpapannaḥ /
analyzed: yat mama antike cittam abhiprasādya kālagataḥ tena cāturmahārājikeṣu deveṣu upapannaḥ
translated: When he passed away with a mind full of faith towards me, he was reborn among the gods of the Four Great Kings.

original: yat kāśyape samyaksaṃbuddhe pravrajitena paṭhitaṃ svādhyāyitaṃ skandhakauśalaṃ dhātukauśalaṃ
analyzed: yat kāśyape samyaksaṃbuddhe pravrajitena paṭhitam svādhyāyitam skandha kauśalam dhātu kauśalam
translated: When he went forth in the teaching of the Perfectly Awakened One Kāśyapa, he recited and studied, and became skilled in the aggregates, skilled in the elements,

original: āyatanakauśalaṃ pratītyasamutpādakauśalaṃ sthānāsthānakauśalaṃ ca kṛtaṃ tena devabhūtena
analyzed: āyatana kauśalam pratītyasamutpāda kauśalam sthāna asthāna kauśalam ca kṛtam tena deva bhūtena
translated: skilled in the sense bases, skilled in dependent origination, and skilled in what is possible and impossible. As a result of that, when he was reborn as a god,

analyzed: mama antike satya darśanam kṛtam
translated: he saw the truths in my presence.

original: iti hi bhikṣavaḥ ekāntakṛṣṇānāṃ karmaṇāṃ pūrvavad yāvad ekāntaśukleṣv eva karmasv ābhogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ ity evaṃ vo bhikṣavaḥ śikṣitavyam
analyzed: iti hi bhikṣavaḥ ekānta kṛṣṇānām karmaṇām pūrvavat yāvat ekānta śukleṣu eva karmasu ābhogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ iti evam vaḥ bhikṣavaḥ śikṣitavyam
translated: Thus, monks, one should apply oneself only to actions that are entirely bright, as before. In this way, monks, you should train.

original: uddānam🔽haṃśa aṭṭo 'thotsṛṣṭo🔽mṛgaḥ pūtiś ca markaṭo gajaḥ
analyzed: uddānam  haṃśa aṭṭaḥ tha utsṛṣṭaḥ  mṛgaḥ pūtiḥ ca markaṭaḥ gajaḥ
translated: Summary:🔽Geese, a crow, and then released,🔽an animal, a stinking monkey, an elephant,
a cat, a bull, a moon-stone,

analyzed: hasti sṛgālaḥ brāhmaṇen ca
translated: an elephant, a jackal, and by a brahmin.

original: bhikṣavaḥ saṃśayajātāḥ sarvasaṃśayacchettāraṃ buddhaṃ bhagavantaṃ papracchuḥ /
analyzed: bhikṣavaḥ saṃśaya jātāḥ sarva saṃśaya chettāram buddham bhagavantam papracchuḥ
translated: The monks, being doubtful, asked the Blessed One, the Buddha, who removes all doubts:

original: paśya bhadanta bhagavān paṃcabhir bhikṣuśataiḥ parityaktaḥ /
analyzed: paśya bhadanta bhagavān paṃcabhiḥ bhikṣu śataiḥ parityaktaḥ
translated: Look, Venerable One, the Blessed One was abandoned by five hundred monks,

analyzed: āyuṣmatā ānandena na parityaktaḥ
translated: but not by the Venerable Ānanda.

analyzed: bhagavān āha
translated: The Blessed One said:

analyzed: na bhikṣavaḥ etarhi
translated: Monks, this is not the first time,

analyzed: yathā atīte pi adhvani abhiḥ parityaktaḥ
translated: but as in the past, he was abandoned by them,

analyzed: ānandena na parityaktaḥ
translated: but not by Ānanda.

analyzed: tat śrūyatām
translated: Listen to that!

original: The story of the king Dhṛtarāṣṭra /
analyzed: the story of the king dhṛtarāṣṭra
translated: The story of King Dhṛtarāṣṭra

original: and his faithful captain Pūrṇamukha / etc /
analyzed: and his faithful captain pūrṇamukha etc
translated: and his faithful captain Pūrṇamukha, etc.

original: concerning a previous birth of Ānanda / etc /
analyzed: concerning a previous birth of ānanda etc
translated: Concerning a previous birth of Ānanda, etc.

original: bhūtapūrvaṃ bhikṣavo 'navatapte mahāsarasi dhṛtarāṣṭro nāma haṃsādhipatir babhūva /
analyzed: bhūta pūrvam bhikṣavaḥ navatapte mahā sarasi dhṛtarāṣṭraḥ nāma haṃsa adhipatiḥ babhūva
translated: Monks, in the past, in the great lake Anavatapta, there was a king of geese named Dhṛtarāṣṭra.

original: tasya dvau putrau pūrṇaś ca pūrṇamukhaś ca /
analyzed: tasya dvau putrau pūrṇaḥ ca pūrṇamukhaḥ ca
translated: He had two sons, Pūrṇa and Pūrṇamukha.

analyzed: pūrṇaḥ jyeṣṭhaḥ pūrṇa mukhaḥ kaniyān
translated: Pūrṇa was the elder, Pūrṇamukha the younger.

analyzed: pūrṇaḥ caṇḍaḥ
translated: Then Pūrṇa was fierce,

analyzed: rabhasaḥ karkaśaḥ
translated: violent, and harsh.

original: nityam eva haṃsān bhartsayati /🔽keṣāṃcit pakṣān utpāṭayati /
analyzed: nityam eva haṃsān bhartsayati  keṣāṃcid pakṣān utpāṭayati
translated: He always scolded the geese.🔽He pulled out the wings of some.

analyzed: keṣāṃcid nakharikābhiḥ kṣatam karoti
translated: He injured some with his claws.

analyzed: etāni ca anyāni ca upadrava śatāni karoti
translated: He did these and hundreds of other harmful things.

original: te haṃsāḥ pratidinam āgamya dhṛtarāṣṭrasya haṃsādhipater nivedayanti /
analyzed: te haṃsāḥ pratidinam āgamya dhṛtarāṣṭrasya haṃsa adhipateḥ nivedayanti
translated: Those geese came every day and reported to Dhṛtarāṣṭra, the king of geese.

analyzed: sa saṃlakṣayati
translated: He thought,

analyzed: pūrṇaḥ caṇḍaḥ rabhasaḥ karkaśaḥ
translated: Pūrṇa is fierce, violent, and harsh.

original: yady aham enaṃ yauvarājye pratiṣṭhāpayāmi mamātyayād eṣa haṃsayūthaṃ nāśayiṣyati /
analyzed: yadi aham enam yauvarājye pratiṣṭhāpayāmi mama atyayāt eṣa haṃsa yūtham nāśayiṣyati
translated: If I establish him as crown prince, after my death he will destroy the flock of geese.

analyzed: tat upāya saṃvidhānam kartavyam iti
translated: Therefore, a plan must be devised.

original: tena pūrṇaḥ pūrṇamukhaś ca ubhāv apy uktau /
analyzed: tena pūrṇaḥ pūrṇamukhaḥ ca ubhau api uktau
translated: He said to both Pūrṇa and Pūrṇamukha,

original: yaḥ utsān sarāṃsi taḍāgāni cāvalokya agrato matsakāsam āgacchati tam ahaṃ haṃsādhipatiṃ sthāpayāmi iti /
analyzed: yaḥ utsān sarāṃsi taḍāgāni ca avalokya agratas mad sakāsam āgacchati tam aham haṃsa adhipatim sthāpayāmi iti
translated: He who, after looking at the ponds, lakes, and pools, comes back with a cough, I will appoint him as the king of the swans.

analyzed: tau anyonyam spardhayā paṃcaśata parivārau
translated: The two of them, competing with each other, set out with retinues of five hundred each.

original: tāv itaś cāmutaś ca utsān sarāṃsi taḍāgāni ca avalokayantāv A
analyzed: tau itas ca amutas ca utsān sarāṃsi taḍāgāni ca avalokayantau a
translated: The two of them, looking at the ponds, lakes, and pools here and there,

analyzed: anupūrveṇa vārāṇasīm nagarīm anuprāptau
translated: eventually reached the city of Vārāṇasī.

original: tena khalu samayena vārāṇasyāṃ brahmadatto nāma rājā rājyaṃ kārayati ṛddhaṃ ca yāvad ākīrṇabahujanamanuṣyaṃ ca /
analyzed: tena khalu samayena vārāṇasyām brahmadattaḥ nāma rājā rājyam kārayati ṛddham ca yāvat ākīrṇa bahu jana manuṣyam ca
translated: At that time, in Vārāṇasī, a king named Brahmadatta was ruling the kingdom, which was prosperous and so on up to being full of many people.

original: tena vārāṇasyām udyānasya nātidūre brahmāvatī nāma puṣkariṇī saraḥprativiśiṣṭatarākhyā /
analyzed: tena vārāṇasyām udyānasya na atidūre brahmāvatī nāma puṣkariṇī saraḥ prativiśiṣṭatara ākhyā
translated: Not far from the park in Vārāṇasī, there was a pond named Brahmavatī, superior to a lake.

analyzed: tasyām nānāvidhāni jala jāni puṣpāṇi ropitāni
translated: In it, various kinds of water-born flowers were planted.

original: tīre samantāc caturṣv api pārśveṣu anekāni puṣpaphalavṛkṣasahasrāṇi ropitāni /
analyzed: tīre samantāt caturṣu api pārśveṣu anekāni puṣpa phala vṛkṣa sahasrāṇi ropitāni
translated: On the banks, on all four sides, many thousands of flowering and fruit-bearing trees were planted.

analyzed: sā utpala kumuda puṇḍarīka saṃchannā aneka taru ṣaṇḍa maṇḍitā bahu vividha vihaga nikūjitā
translated: It was covered with blue, white, and red lotuses, adorned with many trees, and filled with the songs of many different birds.

original: tasyās tāṃ vibhūtiṃ dṛṣṭvā pūrṇo haṃsaḥ paṃcaśataparivāraḥ avatīrya yatheṣṭagatipracāratayā krīḍitum ārabdhaḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ tām vibhūtim dṛṣṭvā pūrṇaḥ haṃsaḥ paṃcaśata parivāraḥ avatīrya yatheṣṭa gati pracāra tayā krīḍitum ārabdhaḥ
translated: Seeing her splendor, the swan Pūrṇa, with a retinue of five hundred, descended and began to play, moving about as he wished.

analyzed: pūrṇamukhaḥ sva yūthyaiḥ ucyate
translated: Pūrṇamukha was told by his own flock,

analyzed: tvam api avatīrya krīḍe iti
translated: You too should descend and play.

analyzed: sa kathayati
translated: He said,

analyzed: rājyam tāvat pratīcchāmi
translated: I will first accept the kingdom.

analyzed: tatas paścāt āgamya krīḍiṣyāmi iti
translated: Then, after that, I will come and play.

original: tena laghu laghv eva gatvā rājyaṃ pratīṣṭaṃ /
analyzed: tena laghu laghu eva gatvā rājyam pratīṣṭam
translated: He quickly went and accepted the kingdom.

original: tataḥ paṃcaśataparivāraḥ vārāṇasīm āgamya brahmāvatīṃ puṣkariṇīm avatīrya krīḍitum ārabdhaḥ /
analyzed: tatas paṃcaśata parivāraḥ vārāṇasīm āgamya brahmāvatīm puṣkariṇīm avatīrya krīḍitum ārabdhaḥ
translated: Then, with a retinue of five hundred, he came to Vārāṇasī, descended into the pond Brahmavatī, and began to play.

original: taṃ tathā pramodavihāriṇaṃ dṛṣṭvā janakāyaḥ saṃśayam āpannaḥ /
analyzed: tam tathā pramoda vihāriṇam dṛṣṭvā jana kāyaḥ saṃśayam āpannaḥ
translated: Seeing him thus enjoying and playing, the people were doubtful.

analyzed: aho parama darśanīyaḥ haṃsādhipatiḥ kutas pi iha saṃprāptaḥ
translated: Oh, how supremely handsome is the lord of swans, who has come from somewhere here!

original: brahmāvatīṃ puṣkariṇīm alaṃkṛtya sarvajalacarān pakṣiṇo rūpaśobhayā abhibhūya lokasya spṛhām utpādayati /
analyzed: brahmāvatīm puṣkariṇīm alaṃkṛtya sarva jalacarān pakṣiṇaḥ rūpa śobhayā abhibhūya lokasya spṛhām utpādayati
translated: Having adorned the pond Brahmavatī, he surpasses all the water creatures and birds with his beauty and splendor, arousing the people's longing.

analyzed: yathā iṣṭam ca viharati iti

translated: Contact has the six sense spheres as its condition. Feeling has contact as its condition. Craving has feeling as its condition.

original: upādānaṃ upādānapratyayo bhavaḥ bhavapratyayā jātiḥ jātipratyayāḥ jarāmaraṇaśokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti /

translated: Clinging has craving as its condition. Becoming has clinging as its condition. Birth has becoming as its condition. Aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair arise from birth.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya samudayo bhavati /

analyzed: asya nirodhāt idam nirudhyate

analyzed: nāma rūpa nirodhaḥ nāma rūpa nirodhāt ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhaḥ ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhāt sparśa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of consciousness, the cessation of name-and-form occurs. From the cessation of name-and-form, the cessation of the six sense spheres occurs. From the cessation of the six sense spheres, the cessation of contact occurs.

analyzed: sparśa nirodhāt vedanā nirodhaḥ vedanā nirodhāt

From the cessation of feeling, the cessation of craving occurs.🔽From the cessation of craving, the cessation of clinging occurs. From the cessation of clinging, the cessation of becoming occurs. From the cessation of becoming, the cessation of birth occurs. From the cessation of birth, aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair cease.🔽Thus ceases this whole great mass of suffering.

analyzed: alpa śabda tāyāḥ ca sa varṇa vādī
